Situation1: A holiday travel surge fills the approach fixes with moderate holding delays.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Story: The radar screen glows with a web of blips, each one a plane circling in the holding pattern, waiting for my clearance. Holiday travel always brings this chaos—voices crackle in my headset, pilots anxious for updates, and I juggle altitudes and vectors, trying to keep the sky safe and the delays minimal. My supervisor expects precision, calm, and above all, no mistakes. In the middle of this, my phone buzzes with a message from a young couple in my congregation. They’re planning their wedding for next year and want to know if I’ll officiate. As their rabbi, I know how much it means to them to have me there, to guide them through the ceremony, to bless their union. I can almost hear their hope in the text. But I can’t check my calendar now, not with a dozen jets stacked up and every second counting. My mind tugs in two directions—toward the sacred trust of my congregation and the relentless demands of the airspace. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, each expecting my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
